text: From tap at Cellarmaker, San Francisco. Aroma is highly tropical with papaya, mango, citrus, notes of peach, light bready malt, including a touch of onion and lots of dankness. Flavour is light sweet with a bitter finish. Body is medium. So damn juicy and well-hopped, amazing.
Pours a hazy pale yellow with a thick white lacing. The aroma Is citrusy apricot and pineapple. The palate is bone dry. Slight onion and metallic

So many flavor-hopped beers go flavor-flat after the first few sips that its usually prudent to order half pints. But the flavors (aromas in the context of tastes) in this beer just keep coming and coming. According to the Oxford Companion to Beer, theres no scientific consensus that the aroma unit (AU) proposed by Nickerson and Van Engel measures what its supposed to measure. (See the "dictionary" entry on "The Aroma Unit (AU)"). But assuming it did, this beers aroma units would easily top 100.
Bright pale yellow hazy pour with a fluffy white head and lacing. Really nice citrus and melon hop nose. Crisp and hoppy with just the right amount of bitterness on a dry finish. Quite nice.
On tap at Cellarmaker. Pours a cloudy yellow golden color with a lovely "glow". Aromas of citrus zest and light dank. Candied orange taste. Solid.

On tap at the brewery. Translucent yellow golden colored pour with a thin fine white head. Aroma is nice tropical fruit, mango pineapple, grainy, straw, citrus. Flavor is composed of a raw base grain, juicy hop, tropical fruit, pineapple, mango, crisp citrus. Firm rounded bitterness. Light dank note in the finish. Palate is medium light, grainy, moderate carbonation. Again this beer has a lovely raw fresh character. Lively stuff.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2016 Draught at Gourmet Haus. Massive tropical aromas. Pineapple. Fresh wheat and a slight cotton candy. Massively hazy yellow with moderate low white head. Taste is juicy fruit - tropics. Slight dank and pine. Moderate bitterness. ** upgrading from a 3.9 - this is fantastic.
Great warm Hoppy aromas. Cloudy golden with a perfect lasting head. A herbal hop flavor that mellows to smooth warm hop finish. Cool refreshing hop finish.
On tap at Cellarmaker. Pours golden with a thick white head and a fruity aroma. There is a hearty pale malt flavor with some tropical fruit and a fairly bitter finiash.

The beer is light and hazy, yellow with a little orange to it. Thick, creamy, white head. Good retention, some lacing. The aroma is juicy with hops and just generally excellent. Bright tangerines, pineapples, grapes, mango, papaya, raspberry, lime, peach. Just a bit of pale malt character in the background. Fresh fruit with a crackly bitter edge. Taste is moderately bitter. Solid hop flavor, more of the same fruitiness. Crisp and light on the palate with a certain creaminess. I dont know if its a mineral addition or something else, but this beer has that almost grainy, creamy heft to the body that really brings out the hop flavor. Normal carbonation. Really tasty stuff. Excellent example of why I keep going back to Cellarmaker.
Light gold pour, white head. Very good beer! Great tropical fruit/melon undertones, some light bitterness. Awesomely juicy.
Very creamy, light golden, sulfur compounds onion, normal cellarmaker goodness, some lingering residual bitterness, herbal geranium

On draft at Caps & Taps. It pours a cloudy yellow color with a white head. The aroma is potent with fresh citrus, tropical fruit, lime rind and white crackers. The flavor has a little hop spice, citrus, lemon/lime, mandarin orange and apricots. Very light crackery malt. The finish is citrusy, floral and dank. Great hop character in this one and no butter at all. Clean and crisp. Everything I love about hoppy beers.

On tap @ Cellarmaker. Hazed orange pour with a white. Slightly buttery up front with a strong grapefruit and orange coming through behind that. A lot of pine, some sweet honey, and peaches. Kinda zesty and floral. Flavor is a bit on the sweet and peachy side. A lot of grass and some herbal notes. A bunch of orange, grapefruit zest, and green melons. Gooseberry on the finish. Pretty nice once you get past the butter.

Color and consistency fits in with like Cellarmaker pales; cloudy but light orange. Mouthfeel is heavy and chewy for a PA, finish lingers pleasantly. Had a familiar twang this brewer is known for, with acidic floral and fruit notes, accompanied by a large sweetness for its style.
From a tap at the brewery. The pour is a orange in color. A really great beer with a apricot, mango juicy hop taste.light to medium body.
